Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) \\) governed by the equation \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a constant. The function is then transformed using \\( f(z) = e^{\\alpha t}z \\), where \\( \\alpha \\) is a real constant, to study its behavior over time.

If the transformation \\( f(z) \\) is applied at t = 0 to an initial condition \\( z_0 \\), and then allowed to evolve according to \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\) without any intervention, will the function \\( z(t) \\) at time T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to time T under the same differential equation?
Explanation: The transformation \\( f(z) = e^{\\alpha t}z \\) changes the magnitude of the initial condition, which modifies the trajectory of the function over time. The growth factor \\( e^{\\alpha t} \\) compounds the effect of the oscillatory behavior governed by \\( i\\omega \\), leading to a different magnitude and potentially different trajectory than if evolved directly.
